cases.title: Kesavananda Bharati vs. State of Kerala
cases.summary: This landmark case established the 'basic structure' doctrine of the Indian Constitution, which rules that the Parliament's power to amend the Constitution is not unlimited and cannot be used to alter its fundamental framework. The case involved a challenge to the 24th, 25th, and 29th Amendments to the Constitution.
cases.subject: Constitutional Law

cases.title: Maneka Gandhi vs. Union of India
cases.summary: The Supreme Court held that the 'procedure established by law' under Article 21 must be fair, just, and reasonable, not arbitrary or oppressive. It significantly expanded the interpretation of the Right to Life and Personal Liberty, introducing the concept of due process.
cases.subject: Constitutional Law

cases.title: D.K. Basu vs. State of West Bengal
cases.summary: The Court laid down detailed guidelines to be followed by police during arrest and detention to prevent custodial torture and abuse of power. These guidelines are mandatory for all police officers and include informing the arrestee of their rights and the grounds of arrest.
cases.subject: Criminal Law

cases.title: Vishaka and others vs. State of Rajasthan
cases.summary: In the absence of any law on the subject, the Supreme Court issued guidelines to prevent sexual harassment of women at the workplace. These 'Vishaka Guidelines' were legally binding until the enactment of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act in 2013.
cases.subject: Women's Rights

cases.title: Shreya Singhal vs. Union of India
cases.summary: The Supreme Court struck down Section 66A of the Information Technology Act, 2000, as unconstitutional for violating the freedom of speech and expression. The Court found the provision to be vague and overly broad.
cases.subject: Cyber Law

cases.title: Navtej Singh Johar vs. Union of India
cases.summary: The Supreme Court decriminalized consensual homosexual acts between adults by partially striking down Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code. The Court held that sexual orientation is a natural and immutable aspect of identity and is protected under the right to privacy.
cases.subject: Constitutional Law

cases.title: Gurbaksh Singh Sibbia vs. State of Punjab
cases.summary: This case extensively dealt with the principles governing the grant of anticipatory bail under Section 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC). The court emphasized that the discretion to grant anticipatory bail should be exercised with care and not in a blanket manner, balancing the individual's right to liberty with the interests of justice and the need for investigation.
cases.subject: Criminal Law

cases.title: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) vs. Union of India
cases.summary: A nine-judge bench unanimously held that the Right to Privacy is a fundamental right under the Indian Constitution, protected under Article 21 (Right to Life and Personal Liberty). This judgment has wide-ranging implications for data protection and individual freedoms.
cases.subject: Constitutional Law

cases.title: Joseph Shine vs. Union of India
cases.summary: The Supreme Court struck down the 158-year-old Section 497 of the Indian Penal Code, which criminalized adultery. The court declared the law unconstitutional, stating that it treated women as property of their husbands and violated their dignity.
cases.subject: Constitutional Law

cases.title: A. K. Gopalan vs. State of Madras
cases.summary: One of the earliest cases that dealt with fundamental rights. The Supreme Court took a narrow view of Article 21, holding that 'procedure established by law' meant any procedure laid down by the legislature. This interpretation was later overturned in the Maneka Gandhi case.
cases.subject: Constitutional Law
